intro: Eriochloa punctata var. acrotricha, commonly known as the narrowleaf buffalo grass, is a perennial grass native to the southern United States and parts of Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, cylindrical stems and narrow, grass-like leaves with a bluish-green hue. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, white to pale green flowers. It is drought-tolerant and thrives in full sun, making it suitable for low-maintenance landscaping. Its fibrous root system helps prevent soil erosion, contributing to its ecological importance in arid regions.
